newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Gaelic Games - Critics say GAA too soft on disciplining players.
newsitem.headline: Gaelic Games - Critics say GAA too soft on disciplining players.

text.p: The Games Administration Committee (GAC) of the GAA should stiffen disciplinary action against players, former inter-county senior football manager Art McRory told Irish national broadcaster, RTE, on Wednesday.
The former Tyrone senior football manager, who led his team to two all-Ireland finals, said match suspensions rather than time suspensions should be handed out for player indiscretions in games.
"The disciplinary rules of the GAA are in serious danger of breaking down if they are not tightened. Penalties for indiscipline must be much more severe," McRory said.

At Tuesday night's meeting of the Games Administration Committee (GAC), suspensions were handed out to 15 players accused of being involved in a brawl in an All-Ireland final replay in Croke Park on September 29.
The GAA's national referee administrator, Paddy Collins, an inter-county referee for 27 years, said the GAA should have an in-depth look at player suspensions.

"A few years the GAA tried to introduce match bans in the National Football League, but (GAA's) membership decided in a democratic fashion that they would not accept the bans and they would not enshrine them in the rules of the official guide," Collins told RTE in a telephone interview on Wednesday.
